title: How to Make Glycerite

steps.headline: Choose a clean, airtight jar to make and store the glycerite in.
steps.description: Avoid using containers that are made from metal or plastic as these will leach chemicals into the glycerite. The size of the jar will determine the amount of glycerite you make. If you only want to make a small batch of glycerite, use a small jar. Glass mason jars are a good and inexpensive option.

steps.headline: Fill the jar 3/4 full with fresh herbs.
steps.description: Pour your herbs into the jar until the jar is about 3/4 full. Don’t pack the herbs down, instead let them sit naturally. If you prefer, you can use dried herbs instead. If so, only fill ⅓ of the jar. Choose 1 herb for the glycerite or experiment with combining different herbs. Lavender, chamomile, calendula, ginger, milky oats, and fennel make nutrient-rich glycerites. These can be combined or used separately. Experiment with different combinations until you find one you like. Lavender and chamomile is a soothing and delicious mix, and a fennel and ginger mix may aid digestion. The nutritional benefits are similar, regardless of whether you use fresh or dried herbs.

steps.headline: Cover the herbs with 100% vegetable glycerine.
steps.description: Pour the glycerine over the herbs until they are completely covered. The glycerine will extract the nutritional properties from the herbs over time, making a concentrated glycerite. Purchase 100% glycerine from a health store.

steps.headline: Stir the glycerite with a butter knife.
steps.description: Gently mix the glycerite until all the herbs are submerged and there are no bubbles coming up from the bottom of the jar. Tightly screw the lid on after you have finished stirring.

steps.headline: Label the jar with the date and name of the herbs you used.
steps.description: Use a permanent marker to clearly label the glycerite. You could also include other details, such as whether the herbs are fresh or dried. This will help you to be able to evaluate your glycerite and guide you if you decide to alter the recipe.

steps.headline: Store the glycerite in a cool, dry cupboard for 4 weeks.
steps.description: Check that the lid is tightly screwed on before placing the jar into the cupboard. Choose a cupboard that doesn’t receive much light or warmth. Avoid using the hot water cupboard.

steps.headline: Shake the jar twice a week and check that the glycerine covers the herbs.
steps.description: Lightly shake the jar a few times a week to mix the herbs through the glycerine. If you notice that some of the glycerine has evaporated, leaving exposed herbs, pour in enough glycerine to cover all the herbs. Screw the lid on tightly before putting the jar back into the cupboard.

steps.headline: Choose a dark glass jar to store the finished glycerite in.
steps.description: You can use a jar with a dropper attached to the lid for easy administering, or use a regular dark glass jar and use your own dropper. Whatever you choose, make sure it's airtight. It is important to use a dark jar to minimise the amount of light exposure the glycerite receives.

steps.headline: Strain the glycerite through a muslin cloth and strainer into a glass jar.
steps.description: Rest a fine-mesh strainer over a clean glass jar. Place 2 layers of muslin cloth over the strainer. Slowly pour the glycerite onto the cloth. Pull the corners of the cloth together and squeeze the herbs to express the liquid that is trapped inside the herbs. Compost the soaked herb leaves or dispose of them in the trash.

steps.headline: Store the glycerite in the fridge or a cool, dark place.
steps.description: Keep the glycerite in an airtight container. The glycerite will last for approximately 1 year if it is kept in the fridge or a dark, cool place. If you notice the lid swelling, this means that the glycerite is fermenting and is unsafe to drink.

steps.headline: Take 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of the glycerite 3 times a day.
steps.description: Different herbal glycerites can be used to treat a variety of ailments. Use the glycerite up to 3 times a day. If you are still feeling unwell in a few days, consult your doctor. Try a liquorice root glycerite. This can be used to treat inflammation and boost immunity. Drink a glass of water afterward if you don’t like the taste.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of the glycerite to a cup of hot water.
steps.description: If you find it difficult to take the glycerite straight, try diluting it in hot water. Add 1 teaspoon (7 grams) of honey to the glass to sweeten the taste. These doses are appropriate for healthy adults. Try using a chamomile or lavender glycerite to aid sleep and calmness.

steps.headline: Consult a doctor before giving a glycerite to children or the very sick.
steps.description: Glycerites are a fantastic health aid, but should not replace professional medical care. Ask your doctor for the appropriate dosage for the age and weight of your child. If you are very unwell, visit a doctor to seek their advice for additional treatment options.
